projects.shortDes: To put my web-dev skills to the test, I created this personal website. No online templates, everything you see here is <bold>from scratch<bold>. Enjoy!
projects.longerDes: I developed this web-app with Javascript and React, styled it with CSS, and deployed it with <bold>Netlify<bold>. There were two parts that were particularly difficult: figuring out the right color/image scheme and also making my website responsive. For color schemes, I just tried out many different combinations, and even did some research on <bold>Gestalt Psychology<bold>. For a responsive website, I used <bold>media queries<bold> and also strong <bold>CSS practice<bold>. After creating this site I have a much greater appreciation for frontend developers!

projects.title: Automated Video Assistant Referee (VAR)
projects.caption: The end result of our program: two lines that'll determine whether attacking player is offsides
projects.caption1: Using k-means to determine which team a player is on
projects.caption2: Using Houghline Transformations to identify the goal-line
projects.shortDes: For my High School Senior Project, I created a <bold>fully automated<bold> system that can determine whether a soccer player is offsides from a video of play. I presented this work to <bold>1000+ students<bold> at tjSTAR
projects.longerDes: Check out my Github Repository if you'd like to see a more detailed explanation on how I did this. But anyways, I first used <bold>yolov5's<bold> common object detection model to detect all the players. I then used <bold>Image Segmentation<bold> and <bold>k-means<bold> to grab the color of all the players' jerseys so that I could figure out the attackers and defenders. Next, I trained a <bold>custom model<bold> myself that can track the ball in the video so that I can find the exact moment the attacking player passes the ball. Finally, I use <bold>Hough-Line Transformations<bold> to find the goal-line so that my program can draw the offsides lines parallel to the goal-line.
